'''Willard L. Thorp''' (1899–1992) was an economist and academic who served three US Presidents, [[Franklin D. Roosevelt]], [[Harry S. Truman]] and [[Dwight D. Eisenhower]] as an advisor in both domestic and foreign affairs. He helped draft the [[Marshall Plan]] and was also prominent in business and education.<ref name="nyt">{{citation|title=Willard L. Thorp, 92, Economist Who Helped Draft Marshall Plan|first=Bruce|last=Lambert|date=May 11, 1992|newspaper=[[New York Times]]|url=http://www.nytimes.com/1992/05/11/us/willard-l-thorp-92-economist-who-helped-draft-marshall-plan.html}}.</ref>

He was [[United States Assistant Secretary of State|Assistant Secretary of State]] under Truman for Economic Affairs 1946–1952;<ref name="nyt"/> A Member of the U.S. delegation serving as special adviser on economic matters at the [[Paris Peace Treaties, 1947|Paris Peace Conference]] of 1946;<ref name="nyt"/> special adviser on economic matters at the New York meeting of the [[Council of Foreign Ministers]] in 1946;<ref name="truman">{{citation|url=http://www.trumanlibrary.org/oralhist/thorpw.htm|title=Oral History Interview with Willard L. Thorp|publisher=Harry S. Truman Library and Museum|first1=Richard D.|last1=McKinzie|first2=Theodore A.|last2=Wilson|date=July 10, 1971|accessdate=2015-03-02}}.</ref> and American representative to the [[United Nations General Assembly]], 1947–48.<ref name="truman"/>

He came under great strain during the [[Joseph McCarthy|McCarthy]] 'witch-hunt' investigations into alleged Communists 1950–1954<ref name="truman"/> and eventually resigned, becoming a professor at [[Amherst College]] again instead.<ref name="nyt"/>
